page.title: 02Crockenhill.A history.
page.content: No history has been written though material is being gathered for one now.It was not in the Domesday Book.The earliest mention of Crokornheld-the slope on which stands a pottery- is in 1388.The medieaval industry was of tile-making and Tylers Green is a very old road name .It remained a hamlet with extensive woods until Victorian times when market gardening,especially strawberry production,expanded rapidily and fortunes were made.Few 16th and 17th century dwellings survive because many old cottages were pulled down and replaced ay the turn of the century by rows of terraced houses.These are now first homes but older people remember families of up to 12 living in the 4 rooms.Fruit farming collapsed in the 1960's and few people work in the village now.
